intro: Anisophyllum macropus, commonly known as the broad-leafed anisophyllum, is a unique member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its distinctive, compound leaves. It typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought conditions. The plant features a tall, unbranched stem with opposite, pinnately divided leaves that are often broad and flat. Its flowers are small and clustered in umbels, typical of the carrot family. Anisophyllum macropus is known for its ability to thrive in poor soils and is sometimes used in ecological restoration projects.
